entry.title: Re: Adobe forms displayed correctly in spool but not corr...
entry.content:
Below are some recommended approaches

  • Use transaction SPAD to inspect and adjust the output device settings. Go to SPAD → Output Devices → Display, select NL-WET-27, check the Format Type (e.g., DINA4, LETTER), ensure the Left and Right Margins are not too narrow. If needed, create a custom format with wider printable area.
  • Open the form in Adobe LiveCycle Designer and set page margins to allow extra space on left/right. Avoid placing critical content too close to the edges. Consider reducing the page width slightly to accommodate printer limitations.
  • Try printing to a different device (e.g., a generic PDF printer or another physical printer) to isolate whether the issue is with NL-WET-27 specifically.

entry.title: Issue Of Non-stock Item To The Work Order
entry.content:
ISSUING NON-STOCK MATERIAL TO WORK ORDER: -

There is a scenario where the material is not present in the inventory, and it needs to be procured from the external vendor then we will just follow the following steps: -

Work process of issuing non-stock items to work order: -

  1. Work order: - A work order is being created and the necessary details like c
  2. omponents and operations are being entered.
  3. Components tab: - here in the components tab the material description will be entered as the material that needs to be procured from the vendor. And also, the item category here will be entered as ‘N’ – non-stock item.
  4. Purchasing data: - the purchasing data must be entered as we have mentioned non-stock items. The purchasing data like purchasing organization, purchasing group, vendor etc.... some of the necessary details will be entered into in the purchasing data.
  5. Converting the purchase requestion into purchase order: - Purchase requestion (PR) will be raised from the order and the Material Management (MM) team will convert the purchase requestion into purchase order (PO).
  6. Converting the purchase order into goods receipt: - After converting into the purchase order, the goods receipt will be done.
  7. No goods issue needed: - Here the goods issue is not needed. When the goods receipt is being done the materials will directly send to the order not into inventory and here you cannot see the stock in the inventory.
  8. Confirmation & TECO: - Confirmation will be done after doing the maintenance activities and then the TECO.
  9. Settlement: - The settlement is being done by the FICO team at the end of the month.

STEP 1: -

Creation of notification will be done based on the requirement that might be whether malfunction (M2) or else maintenance request (M1). Here for example, we will take the maintenance request (M1) It means a machine needs general maintenance in a plant which is being installed in a functional location .

The functional location & equipment details will be maintained by the person at the machine, and he will save the notification. Then after the production supervisor will get in touch with the person who was responsible of creation of notification

STEP 2: -

The production supervisor will go and inspect the machine which is present at the functional location, and he will set the priority, object parts and all the parameters like the object part, tasks , activity etc....

After entering the details of the object part and priority by the production supervisor the notification will be put in the process by clicking on the green flag which is present in the application toolbar.

If any of the tasks need to be performed as well as the causes, the production supervisor will also add them to the notification, and he will also release the tasks too.

Here we can observe the status of the notification.

STEP 3: -

After that we will just create an order based on notification in the T-code IW34 based on notificaiton creation of order.

Here the work order is being created, and the details of the functional location and all the details of the equipment will be picked up from the notification which wa created earlier step .

Here are the operation details and the calculation key will be given  as well as the no.of persons that are required for maintaining the equipment or machine

then the components are maintained in the components tab where the materials that are needed for maintenance and there is one material which is not present in the invenotry.

All the purchasing data will be maintained by the production supervisor and then after he will save the order.

Purchasing organization: - it is responsible for procuring materials or services etc.…

Supplier: - the person who is responsible for giving the goods and services.

G/L account: - for which g/l account the amount needs to be reflected.

Then after that the order will be released and it will be saved.

STEP 4: -

Here the purchase requisition will be raised by the following path: -

Here you can observe the material procurement category for the stock material it is reservation for an order and when it comes to the non-stock item it will be Preq for order.

Select the material and then after just click on the purchasing tab right above it. Here you can observe the details that you have mentioned.

Here the purchase requestion number will be generated, and this purchase requestion will be updated to the MM team or purchasing team which is present in the inventory.

STEP 5: -

Here the material purchase requestion will be converted into the purchase order by using the t-code ME21N. By using the purchase requestion documents overview we will just click on the purchase requestion and then click on the adopt or else we can just drag and drop the purchase requestion. 

We will just click on check and then after we will just save it.

STEP 6: -

After converting the purchase requestion into a purchase order then goods receipt will be done against the purchase order in the transaction code: - MIGO.It means the goods which are being procured from vendor needs to be updated right so we will just do goods reciept against the purchase order. 

Here the movement type will be 101 – goods receipt against the purchase order and the checkbox needs to be checked. Then after click on the check and post. After clicking on post the materials will not be displayed in the inventory and those materials will directly send to the accounts.

Here the material is being procured and then after the invoice will be done based on PO.

STEP 7: -

The invoice will be raised against the purchase order and the invoice will be done in the transaction code: -MIRO.

Here the details of the purchase order will be picked up automatically. And the checkbox calculates tax needs to be checked, and the tax code needs to be entered in the po reference box and then the item ok checkbox too.

Enter the amount in the basic data tab and this is the amount that needs to be sent to the vendor.

Now after this we will just click on stimulate which is present in the application toolbar.

Now just click on save or post.

Note: - Steps 5, 6, 7 are mostly done by material management (MM) team.

STEP 8: -

Now just go back to your order and here just see the materials issued for the order by using the following path.

Now here the materials are being issued to the order.

STEP 9: -

After the materials are being procured and issued to the order the technician will perform the maintenance on the equipment and after performing the maintenance the confirmation will be done through t-code IW41.

STEP 10: -

After confirmation the technical confirmation will be done by going into the change mode of the order. TECO will clear all the material reservations that are being done for any other materials.

STEP11:-
Here after performing the technical confirmation the FICO team will perform the settlement for the order in KO88.Generally the settlement will be done at the end of the month.

Accounting document: -

Controlling documents: -

SUMMARY:-

When a non-stock material is required for a work order and is not available in inventory, a notification is created, and a maintenance order is generated in IW34 with the material entered as item category N along with purchasing details. Releasing the order creates a purchase requisition, which the MM team converts to a PO in ME21N. A goods receipt in MIGO (movement type 101) sends the material directly to the order without adding it to inventory. The vendor invoice is processed in MIRO, the maintenance is confirmed in IW41, the order is technically completed in IW32, and finally, the FICO team settles it in KO88.

The above describes the process of procuring the materials from external or vendor. Feel free to provide any comments or suggestions.

Regards ,
Neeraj

Thanks. The concern is what we called 'unclean' in the previous tier-3 extensibility model, we are calling many of those 'clean' under Level B in this version. All the classical extensibility was 'unclean' as per the documents shared by SAP for partners. We kept on preaching our clients certain things are not clean, and suddenly those becomes 'clean'! entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in...
entry.content:
561Q is used for initial entry into unrestricted project stock. It’s typically applied during initial data migration, such as during go-live or mergers/acquisitions. This movement adds stock to the project but does not consume budget or reflect in project line item reports, because it’s not considered a consumption or expense transaction.

Why it doesn’t reflect in Line Item or Budget is because, Project line item reports track actual costs posted to the project (WBS element or network). 561Q posts stock to inventory (Balance Sheet account), not to a cost object (Profit & Loss account). Since there’s no account assignment to a cost object, it doesn’t trigger budget consumption or appear in cost reports.

To ensure stock movements reflect in both project line item reports and budget consumption, consider:

Use Consumption Movement Types:

  • 221Q – Consumption for project from project stock.
  • 261Q / 281Q – Consumption for order or network from project stock.
  • These post to cost objects and consume budget.

Check Account Assignment:

  • Ensure materials are assigned to the correct WBS element or network.
  • Use movement types that trigger postings to P&L accounts.

Review whether the G/L accounts linked to movement types are correctly set up to post to cost objects. Use report RM07CUFA to reconcile field selections between G/L accounts and movement types

entry.title: Re: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
Hi ADR,

please send me an email with details and link to the document shared with partners. 
About naming the main idea behind was to avoid a kind of binary rating of clean core. For greenfield implementations it is still valid. Stay in level A. Break out in B if really needed (Tier2-Wrappers). Always Rethink if you really need the extension there. In best case always no!

in brownfield projects make a split between existing code and new code.

New code shall follow greenfield approach. In best case no extension and use more standard.

For existing code, make a retirement of unused code, leverage level A or B. Put C in observation mode, decouple and refactor for real company benefits.

Please contact your assigned partner manager to get updates and details. Visit Partner Edge Website for further information related to partner and certification process.

SAP Ariba Category Management simplifies external spend and supplier management for businesses. Built on the SAP Business Technology Platform, this extensible and integrated solution offers valuable market intelligence and category insights to category managers and procurement professionals.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 4: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More)
entry.content:
This fourth post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP SuccessFactors. It covers Joule and many AI-based UX innovations along with enhanced user experiences. By following the career of Jon, who starts by applying for a job and then grows within the company, you can see how our latest user experience innovations help business users (employees and managers), work more effectively.

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Also, if you missed it, do have a look at the many UX innovations which already came out end of last year with the SAP SuccessFactors 2H2024 release:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 3: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More).

The 1H2025 release comes with a large number of UX innovations across the whole portfolio. In the following sections, I’ll summarize the main highlights by following the career of Jon, and showing how the new AI-powered UX innovations help:

  • Jon find the right job with the help of the new guided application experience.
  • Managers move through the hiring process more efficiently, rating skills and competencies of candidates with Joule, and getting AI-assisted interview insights.
  • Jon understand the main features available to him in his employee HR applications.
  • Jon get an easy-to-understand overview of his benefits and payroll.
  • Jon use natural language with Joule to get questions answered and detailed information about pay statements, not only from at his desk but also via mobile phone.
  • Jon learn more, with learning overview and skilled-based learning recommendations.
  • Jon and his manager to manage goals and performance reviews, with AI-insights making his manager’s job a lot easier.

One more innovation is the new alumni experience, for departing and departed employees, helping them to

  • Manage personal information and access important documents during and after the off-boarding process.

To get the complete picture of all the new SuccessFactors innovations, have a look at the links in the “Further Information “ section towards the end of this post.

 

Find the Right Job With New Guided Application Experience

Jon is applying for a job at a company which uses SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, and finds the whole process very intuitive, thanks to the new guided application experience, as well as the further enhancements in the reimagined candidate experience.

Figure 1 shows the new guided application experience. This attractive UI guides applicants through the required steps, with AI-assistance provided along the way. For example, Figure 1 shows the AI button “Suggest Skills”, which can help candidates when listing their own skills by indicating other skills which they may also have but did not consider mentioning.

Figure 1: Guided job application experience with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A screenshot of a six-step guided activity, with the six steps running horizontally across the top of the screen: “Getting Started”, “Profile”, “Skills Information”, “Employment”, “Education”, “Review”. The screen shows “Skills Information”, with ten skills already selected, a search field for adding a skill and an AI “Suggest Skills” button.

Once Jon has gone through the guided steps, he can use the updated and refreshed applications dashboard that gives an overview of his applications with easy access to post-application steps, and to completed and in-progress applications. If Jon wants to review his candidate profile and make adjustments, this is also easier now with the refreshed candidate profile. See examples of these, and more, here:

  • Blog post: 1H 2025: Explore the Reimagined Candidate Experience and New AI-Assisted Capabilities in Recruiting.
  • Documentation: The Reimagined Candidate Experience.

 

Joule and AI-Assisted Interview Insights Help Managers Recruit

Providing Interview Feedback with Joule

Once the interview has taken place, each interviewer needs to summarize their feedback on the candidates, such as Jon. This can now be done easily using Joule and natural language, where you can say who you want to give feedback for and assing the ratings all in one go, as you can see in Figure 2.

Figure 2: Providing interview feedback with Joule. Alt Text: An image of Joule showing a chat, with the first entry by the user being “Mike Wang”, followed by a text asking the user to provide feedback for him, explaining the scale 1 to 5 and providing a text for copying into the chat listing the five areas to rate, and a line for overall comment and one for recommendation. The user has copied the text into their response and added the ratings, comment and recommendation (“yes”). 

AI-Assisted Interview Insights

When multiple interviewers are involved, the recruiting manager needs to consolidate the feedback from all of them, based on their ratings of competencies as well as individual remarks. This is where the AI-assisted interview insights comes in handy: by clicking on the AI “generate” button, the manager gets a natural language summary of the interviewer’s feedback on the candidate Jon. This is provided in sections Overview, Strengths, Concerns, Interviewer’s Overall Feedback, with a separate section Data Referenced that provides an overview of the inputs used to create the AI-assisted insights. Figure 3 shows an example, and Figure 4 shows it in action.

Not only does this help the manager save time and be more efficient, it also helps her be more effective: the feedback across multiple candidates is consolidated consistently, ensuring that all aspects of a candidate’s interview feedback are consolidated and uniformly presented. Furthermore, key insights are highlighted.

Figure 3: AI-assisted interview insights with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a pop-over with interview insights in natural langauge, in sections “Overview”, “Strengths”, “Concerns”, and “Interviewer’s Overall Feedback”. Bottom right has an AI button “Regenerate” and a button “Close”.

Figure 4: AI-assisted interview insights in action with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A short video (GIF) showing a user press the AI button “Generate” and showing the resulting insights, similar to what is shown in Figure 3.

Find out more:

  • 1H 2025: Revolutionizing Hiring Decisions with AI Interview Feedback Insights in SAP SF Recruiting.
  • Documentation: AI-Assisted Interview Feedback Insights.

 

Onboarding Made Easy with WalkMe

Jon got the job, and getting started is made easy for him with the onboarding checklist I featured in my February blog post. Now, when he starts using SAP SuccessFactors for the first time, to get some of his on-boarding tasks done, he gets built-in guidance via WalkMe, which explains applications step by step.

Figure 5 shows an example for when Jon opens up the Employee Profile, he gets an explanation about the purpose of the Profile Preview. Clicking on “Next” takes him to a brief explanation of the “Spotlight”.

Figure 5: An example of WalkMe providing guidance for SAP SuccessFactors users: first explaining the People Profile (upper image), then explaining the Spotlight (lower image). Alt Text: The upper image shows the People Profile for a user, with contact details on the left and cards for Skills, Competencies, Mentoring, Organization, About Me Video, Upcoming Absence on the right. A pop-over hovers above the list on the left with an explanation of the purpose of the People Profile and two buttons “Next” and greyed-out “Back”.

Easy-to-Understand Overview of Benefits and Payroll

Now that Jon is more familiar with SAP SuccessFactors, and has been on the job for a while, he’d like to get an overview of the various benefits he has enrolled in, along with details of his payroll, such as his pay statement along with pay related information. This is now easy with the enhanced People Profile in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, which provides quick access to the various parts of your benefits (Figure 6) and payroll information (Figure 7). These pages list all the relevant parts, with direct links for more information on each of them.

Figure 7: Payroll information in the enhanced People Profile in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central. Alt Text: Screenshot of People Profile with the list of sections on the left, “Payroll” selected. On the right one card “Payroll” is shown, with a title “Payroll Information (1 of 3)” and a greyed out left-arrow button and a right-arrow button above a list of items and links.

Have a look at all the enhancements to People Profile in this video, or read about them in this blog post:

  • Video: 1H2025 release highlights – people profile (32 seconds)
  • First Half 2025 Release: What’s New in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central?

Understand Pay Statements with Natural Language via Joule – also Mobile

Jon has used Joule from his browser to answer various HR questions, as well as for creating leave requests. Now, he can use Joule on the go with the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app – as I explained in my Part 1 blog post.

Jon had a look at his pay statement, via the enhanced People Profile we just talked about, and wasn’t quite sure whether he understood how it all fits together (something probably familiar to most people starting out in a job).  Fortunately, he can simply ask Joule to get a natural language explanation of the pay statement, as you can see in Figure 8.

Figure 8: Using Joule to explain your pay statement. Alt Text: An image of Joule showing a chat, with the first entry by the user being “Explain my pay”, followed by a text explaining the current month’s payslip in four sections “Gross Pay”, “Deductions”, “Net Pay” and “Employer Contributions”, and a reminder to check your payslip regularly to ensure tax code and other details are correct.

In figure 8, he simply asked “Explain my pay” and already got a concise summary  in natural language. He started asking “Why are my deductions so high?”. If you want to see how Joule responds to that, and more, watch:

  • Video: 1H2025 release highlights – explain my pay with Joule (35 seconds)

 

Learning Overview and Skill-Based Recommendations

Learning and Development in Enhanced People Profile

Jon is keen to progress in his career and learn more. The enhanced People Profile now includes a “Learning and Development” overview, as shown in Figure 9. Jon gets an overview of his development goals, assignments from the opportunity marketplace, learning history, and required learning, with links to more information and actions.

Figure 9: Learning and development information in the enhanced People Profile in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central. Alt Text: Screenshot of People Profile with the list of sections on the left, “Learning and Development” selected. On the right four cards are shown: Development Goals, Opportunity Marketplace Assignments, Learning History, Required Learning. Each has a list of items each with links, and a card-specific link at the bottom to go the application for the card’s topic.

Skill-Based Learning Recommendations

Based on Jon’s skills and his respective proficiency levels, Jon can now look at a particular skill in the Growth Portfolio which he would like to develop further, and get a learning recommendation from SAP SuccessFactors in the “Opportunities to Grow” section. Get a 30-second glimpse of this at 1:59 in this video:

  • Video: SAP SuccessFactors 1H 2025 Release Highlights.

 

Managing Goals and Performance Reviews

Towards the end of the year, it’s time for performance reviews and setting up goals for the next year. With the 1H2025 release, we are introducing a brand new user experience for doing this, with a new UI and several AI-assisted capabilities to help Jon and his manager get this done efficiently with good outcomes.

Figure 10 shows the new UI for managing performance, where you can see your goals, your skills, your ratings and your manager’s rating along with ratings from others.

Figure 10: The new performance form experience in SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals. Alt Text: Screenshot of the new form for performance, with the left two-thirds starting with a section for generating AI-powered insights, then “Your Goals” and “Your Skills” as lists with a slider for each entry depicting the rating, columns for employee rating, gap, weight and comment. The goal “Increase sales by $100 million” has been selected. On the right details of the selected goal are shown, with sections “Rating and Comment”, “Ratings from Others” and “Linked Activity (2)”.

Jon’s manager finds it easier to craft helpful feedback by using the following new AI-assisted features:

  • AI-assisted comments, which uses the AI-writing assistant in order to help formulate comments.  (The AI writing assistant was first introduced a year ago, see my blog post from last summer).
  • AI-assisted feedback in performance reviews, which integrates rating context as well as user input to create recommendations for feedback texts.

To see the above in action, watch this:

  • Video: 1H 2025 release highlights - revamped performance form with AI (39 seconds).

Jon himself benefits from the new AI-based sentiment analysis for 360-degree reviews, shown in Figure 11. With this, he can quickly identify positive, negative or mixed feedback, as well as seeing which areas need improvement, thus aiding him in developing as a professional.

Figure 11: AI-based sentiment analysis for 360-degree reviews in SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Detailed 360 Report in the background showing partly covered horizontal bar charts for ratings from Manager, Self, Direct Report/Peer/Other, All Except Self and All. The center contains a pop-over “Communicating Effectively – Comments” showing two anonymous comments, the first one labelled “positive”, the second one “mixed”.

 To find out more about all the exciting innovations in SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, including the ones just mentioned, look at this blog post:

  • First Half 2025 Release: What is New for SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals?

 

AI-Assisted Offboarding and New Alumni Experience

With this release, we provide AI-assistance to employees who are departing, via AI-assisted offboarding through Joule. This helps employees complete their tasks, providing them with a well-structured offboarding experience.

The new alumni experience goes one important step further, by giving ex-employees access to personal information, documents and resources – and hence a much better overall user experience than before. Figure 12 shows the home page for alumni, giving them direct access to pay statements, profile, documents and personal information. They also get access to payroll and tax-related documents.

Figure 12: The new alumni home page in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding. entry.title: Re: Missing Create external document(URL) button in GOS o...
entry.content:
Hi @nagao_masahiro_ 

Thank you for your message.

Please note, the “Create external document” button in the Generic Object Services panel for ME21N is not available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508, while it does exist in the on-premise edition. The primary reason is that SAP S/4HANA Cloud limits certain legacy functionalities like GOS attachment features. It focuses instead on standard cloud-based document management via the Attachment Service and the Manage Documents Fiori app.

Here are points to understand:

Please note, S/4HANA Cloud has stricter security, standardization, and reduced customisation. Compared to On-Premise, this includes limited or reimagined GOS features.

For external documents and URLs, as a Cloud edition user, ensure you use the Manage Documents app or other supported document management tools, not GOS.

The SAP cloud product roadmap may bring more features, but legacy options available on-premise are often replaced or omitted in the Cloud due to architectural differences and focus on newer Fiori solutions.

If you specifically need to attach a URL, you have the possibility to investigate cloud-native options via Attachment Service or request an SAP enhancement for your business process.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: production order Work in progress settlement is not r...
entry.content:
If your system is already set up for Settlement, follow the below steps

If you are not sure on this, follow the below steps

Periodic Settlement to WBS

This transfers actual costs (including WIP if configured) from the production order to the WBS element. It ensures that your project reflects the incurred costs even before the order is fully settled.

Final Settlement to Material

Once the production order is technically complete or fully delivered, you do a final settlement. This moves the costs from the WBS to the inventory (material), completing the cost flow.

entry.title: Re: impossible to add document for virtual assets and non...
entry.content:
Hi @Joo_Leo 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through possible scenarios.

The reason you are facing the issue lies in the fact that, in SAP Business One, you cannot mix virtual assets and regular items or non-virtual assets in the same document. SAP explicitly blocks this to ensure correct asset capitalization and inventory management.

You have the possibility to resolve the issue by creating separate purchase orders. One for virtual assets and another for regular inventory items or non-virtual assets

Please ensure to review your purchase order. If it includes both types of items, split them into different documents as required. If you are unsure which items are classified as virtual assets, I suggest you check the asset settings or consult asset master data for items marked with the virtual asset flag.

If this error still persists for items you believe are not virtual assets, please ensure to review their definitions and ensure proper field setup per SAP guidelines.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: ABAP Extensibility Guide – Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
Hi Community,

"

  • Level B can be achieved by custom extensions that comply with SAP recommendations for the use of classic ABAP development technologies and the frameworks offered as classic SAP APIs
  • Level C contains custom extensions which cannot be qualified for Level B because of usage of arbitrary SAP internal objects. Under the condition that dedicated checks are performed before the release upgrade (following the changelog for SAP objects approach), these custom extensions can be considered conditionally clean.
  • Level D is not clean core and includes custom extensions with severe violations of SAP development recommendations like modifications, usage of not recommended SAP objects or extension technologies (e.g. implicit enhancements)."

Thanks for your sharing, it really help us great a lot.

🙂

 

Regards,

ZFiori.

entry.title: Re: Tax Compliance Tool
entry.content:
Hi @harishram 

Thank you for question.

The SAP Document and Reporting Compliance can manage most of the VAT compliance lifecycle. Ranging from data extraction and return preparation to electronic submission with workflow approvals, audit trail, and a compliance calendar to track deadlines. These Workflow notifications can be enabled through the Document Reporting Compliance dashboard or SAP workflow integration.

However, note that direct VAT payment tracking or automation is not a core Document Reporting Compliance function. Payment status can be monitored indirectly through integration with financial modules. Please note that the Run Statutory Reports app focuses only on report generation and submission, which means it does not cover the complete process and workflow steps.

In short, Document Reporting Compliance can handle end‑to‑end VAT reporting and submission with workflows and compliance tracking but payment management may require integration with other SAP modules.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP ABAP Classical Workflow: A complete guide (Part- 2)
entry.content:
Part-1 explains the classical workflow definition, technical requirements, BADI exits for standard transactions, business object and event creation, definitions of step types, container elements, and the binding process.

What will you learn from this blog?

Workflow builder creation in SWDD, element container creation, step type creation, binding process, and workflow debugging techniques.

Important transaction codes:

  • SWDD- Workflow builder creation or display
  • SBWP- SAP Business Workplace user inbox
  • PFTC- Create/Change/Display Tasks
  • SWIA- Display Workflow instances
  • SWUS- Test Workflow
  • SWDP- Workflow Log

Step 3.1: Creation of Container elements

 

The Element & Name should be the same as the business object event parameters and BADI 'lt_container' table as shown below.

 

All required element containers have been created to match the event parameters that were already defined in BO.

Step 3.2: Call the BO & Event in the workflow builder

The event parameter values are passed to the workflow builder through the workflow element container. 

Step 3.3: Create a Step type multiple condition 

As per our requirement, we have to send the user decision to the respective level of approvers based on NETPR, that already mentioned in part-1 blog.

I have split lower-level and higher-level approval by using the field 'LEVEL' values. 

For example: NETPR < 200.00 Rs then it is LEVEL1 (Lower Level),

                          NETPR > 200.00Rs then it is LEVEL2( Higher level).

Step 3.4: Create an activity step for the lower level to import the approver username from the GET_USER method in BO.

The method GET_USER is not a dialogue process, so enable the background processing option. In the container tab, we have to create the element containers for importing values from that method.

Now we have to complete the binding process for the activity step. I have exported the 'LEVEL' value to the method and imported the 'USERNAME' values returned from the method to the workflow builder. 

I have marked all element containers as both import and export types, so they are bound for both processes.

Step 3.5: Create Block & User decision steps for lower-level approvals:

Go to the dynamic processing tab and provide the multiline element for which you want line-by-line iteration. If you have any condition to stop the block (iteration), then you give that condition to the 'End condition' option.

In binding, it will create an element as a single line value.

Step 3.6: Create User decision

Create again the element containers import from workflow builder to this generic decision step to show those are in the user decision's description page, and complete the binding process.

As I already mentioned, I marked containers as both import and export, so they are bound for both processes.

Step 3.7: Process control

This is used to complete the workflow if any of the users reject the workflow at a particular level.

Now the lower-level approval workflow builder has been completed and shown as below.

Step 3.8: Create a Loop until the step for the high-level approver

For this step, I created two more element containers, EXIT_COND & USCOUNT.

 

Loop Until step:

EXITCOND- Initial value is 1 and it will increase in each loop iteration, if any of the approvers rejects the exit condition is set to 0 value.

USCOUNT- It is the total number of line items of the high-level approver internal table, the logic implemented in BO (part-1).

Step 3.9: Create an activity step for high-level approval

Create an element container to import the values from the GET_USER method. The difference between the low-level and high-level approval activity steps is:

  • Low-level approval – We pass only the LEVEL parameter to fetch the approver usernames.
  • High-level approval, we pass the EXIT_COND along with the LEVEL parameter, which retrieves both the USCOUNT (user count) and a single approver username.

Complete the binding process.

Step 3.10: Create a user decision step for high-level approval

I used the same user decision task, which was already defined for lower-level approval, but the expression only differs.

Define expression on the Decision tab -> go to control tab and double click the task number -> create element container for this generic decision task in container tab -> Create description in description tab -> complete the binding in control tab.

Step 3.11: Create Container operation for both approver and reject decisions

  • If the user approves the work item, then the exit condition value should increase by using the container operation.
  • If the user rejects the work item, then the exit condition value should be 0 by using the container operation.

Approve process:

Reject Process:

Below are the completed steps of high-level approval

Below is an overall view of the workflow builder for this process.

Step 4: Execute and debug the workflow 

4.1: For low-level, the amount is below 200.00 Rs

Go to the business object, set the external break-point in the method GET_USER and change the user to SAP_WFRT through utilities-> settings -> ABAP EDITOR -> Debugging -> User 

Now changing the purchase order amount below 200 in the ME21/22N transaction.

Once the PO is saved, the break-point will be triggered like below.

The workflow user decision will trigger the below users one by one, i.e. the user decision will send to 2nd user after the first user approves.

Go to the transaction SBWP workflow inbox to approve/reject the user decision

In the below graphical workflow, we can able to see how the workflow is executed.

Now I have approved the work item from my inbox and see the current workflow log.

 

After the second user approved the work item.

Step 4.2: The level 1's Initial approver rejects the workflow 

This is how the step type 'Process Control' works to end the workflow.

Step 4.3: For high-level, the amount is below 200.00 Rs

In the above screenshot, we can see that the steps 'Fetch user' and 'User decision' are in a loop process. Let's see this in a graphical log.

Step 4.4: The level 2's Initial approver rejects the workflow 

 

Conclusion:

In this workflow builder, both the Block and Loop (Until) steps perform the same process. I just want to demonstrate how each of them works and how to set the exit condition when using a loop or a block.

Thanks for your time!

entry.title: Supercharge your view of Connected Business Partners
entry.content:
Introduction

It’s a common headache in SAP Business One: a company shows up in both ledgers—vendor and customer—and the net position isn’t obvious during day-to-day work. In SAP Business One, link the two records using the 'Connected Customer/Vendor' field in BP Master Data (Accounting) so the relationship is explicit in the system. Once the records are linked, the standard tools—Dunning, Aging, and Internal Reconciliation—become much more useful for seeing the combined relationship. The foundational aspects of handling these dual-role scenarios are valuable topics within the SAP Business One community. This article provides practical tips to enhance your control over these relationships.

In practice, most teams want faster, on‑form visibility and safeguards. Here's what actually delivers that. This article delves into practical custom enhancements you can implement in SAP Business One. We'll cover how to empower users through:

  • Adding dynamic User-Defined Fields (UDFs) with live balance queries to critical forms like Outgoing Payments.
  • Implementing automated alerts to stay informed about key connected BP statuses.
  • Introducing transaction validations (via SBO_SP_TransactionNotification) to prevent issues, such as unnecessary payments to vendors who are also indebted to us as customers.

Connecting Business Partners

To link a customer and a vendor in SAP Business One, you can use the 'Connected Customer/Vendor' field within the accounting tab in Business Partner Master Data.

💡    The [ConnBP] database field in the OCRD table (Business Partner Master Data table) stores this link, and connect two distinct BP records.

Connected Vendor/Customer field in BP Master Data


Standard SAP Business One Tools for Managing Connected BPs

1.    Dunning Wizard: This tool can be configured to consider the connected relationship, providing a comprehensive report for both the primary BP and its connected counterparts by selecting the relevant options in the Dunning Wizard.

Dunning Wizard for connected BPs

2.    Customer/Vendor Aging Reports: These reports can also display all related documents for connected business partners, offering a unified view.

Customer/Vendor Aging Reports

3.    BP Internal Reconciliation: After reviewing the status of connected BPs (e.g., via Aging Reports or your custom query), the Internal Reconciliation feature can be used. While standard internal reconciliation typically applies to transactions within a single BP account, understanding the consolidated picture can guide manual journal entries or offsetting transactions that effectively reconcile the net position between a connected customer and vendor when submitting financial documents.

BP Internal Reconciliation

Internal Reconciliation

Going Beyond Standard Tools: Custom Enhancements for Superior Control

Beyond the built‑in functions, a few small customizations can give you tighter control in daily business:

1.    Custom Queries for Real-time Tracking & Proactive Alerts: You can create specific SQL queries to get an immediate overview of these relationships. This query can then be added to a user's 'My Menu' for quick access.

SELECT
    V.CardCode,
    V.CardName,
    C.CardCode,
    C.CardName,
    C.Balance AS CustomerBalance,
    V.Balance * -1 AS VendorBalance,
    V.Balance + C.Balance AS NetBalance
FROM OCRD V
INNER JOIN OCRD C ON V.CardCode = C.ConnBP
WHERE V.CardType = 'S' AND C.CardType = 'C'
ORDER BY V.CardCode;

🔗    This query provides a real-time snapshot of vendor-customer balances, aiding decision-making. The full code is on GitHub.

Connected BP Balance Query
Set up the balance query as a scheduled Alert: if the connected customer is overdue beyond your limit and the vendor has a payment due, AP gets a notification.

Setting up alerts for connected BP balances

Messages/Alerts Overview

💡   For scheduled alerts, ensure the SAP Business One Job Service (Alerts) component is installed and running on your server, and that Alert Management is enabled in General Settings.

2.    Implementing Transaction Validations via Stored Procedure

To prevent potential issues, such as making a large payment to a vendor who, as a connected customer, has a significant overdue balance, you can implement validations directly within SAP Business One transactions.

You can do this by adding a rule in the SBO_SP_TransactionNotification stored procedure: when an Outgoing Payment is added for a vendor, check the connected customer's overdue balance and block it if it's over your set limit. For example, when an Outgoing Payment is being added for a vendor, your stored procedure can check if this vendor has a connected customer account with an overdue balance. Based on predefined conditions (e.g., if the customer's overdue amount exceeds a certain threshold), the procedure can block the payment and display an error message to the user, prompting them to review the consolidated account status before proceeding.

🔗    This way, you avoid paying a supplier who is overdue as a customer. The complete stored procedure is available on GitHub.

Validations via Stored Procedure

3.    User-Defined Fields (UDFs) for Instant Visibility on Forms

Add UDFs on Outgoing Payments and drive them with Formatted Searches so that when a vendor is picked, the connected customer code and both balances appear instantly. When a vendor is selected, these UDFs can automatically display the code of any connected customer and their relevant balances.

Used-Defined Fields - Management

When a vendor is selected on the Outgoing Payment form, if they have a customer linked using the 'Connected Customer' field (in BP Master Data), the UDF for 'Connected BP Code' will auto-populate. Subsequently, other UDFs can display the connected customer's balance and the main vendor's balance using Formatted Searches linked to custom SQL queries.

Outgoing Payments form with UDFs for a linked customer

These UDFs use the Formatted Search feature to automatically fetch and display relevant data via linked SQL queries.

💡    To assign a Formatted Search to a UDF (or any field), select the field on the form and press 'Alt + Shift + F2'  to open the 'User-Defined Values - Setup' window.

Used-Defined Values

If no customer is connected to the selected vendor, the 'Connected BP Code' UDF will be empty, and the 'Customer Balance' UDF will display zero.

Outgoing Payments Form for a Vendor with No Linked Customer


Conclusion

Adding a few well‑chosen UDFs, a targeted alert, and one or two validation rules can make SAP Business One much easier to use when a vendor is also a customer—giving your team a clearer view, more control, and fewer mistakes.

 

Prepared by

Amirhossein Tonekaboni
SAP Business One ERP Consultant

  • GitHub
  • LinkedIn
  • Allmylinks

SAP and SAP Business One are trademarks of SAP SE. This article is an independent publication by the author and not an official SAP statement.

entry.title: Re: Supplier login issues
entry.content:
Hi @JJ321 

That issue can occur due to several common scenarios in SAP Ariba registration. Let us walk through potential scenarios. Often, the error means the username or account the supplier tries to use is already linked to another supplier profile or buyer system. Ariba requires unique usernames, so attempts to reuse an existing username for a new registration cause error.


Another reason could be that the supplier’s Ariba Business Network account might already be linked to your company’s buyer system but under a different supplier profile. If a new registration uses the same account but different profile information, it will fail with an account-linking error.


Also note that sometimes, multiple supplier organizations exist for the same company in your buyer system. One might be linked to the ANID, while others are not. Inviting the supplier to an unlinked profile causes errors until the accounts are reconciled.


There is also the possibility that the buyer system might have disabled automatic synchronization of additional users from the supplier organization and therefore may result in missing links between user accounts and buyer profiles.

To pinpoint potential solution, I suggest you evaluate the following:

  • Ensure to verify if your supplier’s existing Ariba Business Network account (ANID) is already linked to your buyer system via supplier profiles.
  • Then check for duplicate or multiple supplier organizations under your buyer realm for the same company and unify or unlink as needed.
  • Ask your supplier to log in with their existing username and password rather than creating a new account. If necessary, reassign the supplier’s questionnaire, event, or invitation to the correct user profile linked to the existing account.
  • Make sure your supplier uses Ariba Administrator tools Manage > Supplier and Customer Manager > Users to review linked accounts and resolve conflicts. If the supplier forgot their credentials, advise them to use the “Forgot Username or Password” process.
  • Finally, ensure that your supplier is not attempting to link the same ANID to multiple supplier organizations, which is not allowed. If synchronization is disabled by the buyer, enable or troubleshoot it in your system settings.

By following these steps, most of the errors faced while registering and linking can be resolved without requiring the supplier to create new accounts. If the issue persists, I recommend contacting SAP Ariba support with detailed account and error info.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: AI Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors: A New Level of Support for Recruiters
entry.content:
AI Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors: A New Level of Support for Recruiters

As someone who has spent years in Talent Acquisition, I've often found myself buried under stacks of resumes, trying to find that perfect candidate. It's repetitive work that can be exhausting. That's why I'm excited to share how SAP SuccessFactors' new AI-powered applicant screening is a game-changer for people like me in recruitment.

Simplifying the Screening Process

The AI feature in SAP SuccessFactors does more than just save time—it offers smart insights to help us zero in on the best candidates. The AI engine matches a candidate's skills to the job requirements not just by looking for exact matches but also by identifying related and transferable skills.

One of my favorite aspects of this tool is how it orders candidates, showing us who is the strongest match and who might be less relevant. Here’s how this benefits us as recruiters:

  • Efficient Screening: No more manually sifting through every resume.
  • Highlighting Strong Candidates: The best candidates rise to the top automatically.
  • Time-Saving: We’ve seen up to 80% reduction in screening time, and a 25% faster time-to-fill rate thanks to this feature.

Visit here: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/ai-feature/3ea4fec4-1f6d-4865-9459-54ac5b337641

How It Works—The Basics

Here's a simple breakdown of how the system operates:

  1. Job Creation: The AI extracts skills from your job description. You have the option to tweak it to your liking.
  2. Application Processing: Resumes are scanned for matching, related, and missing skills.
  3. Recruiter Dashboard: It presents matches clearly, showing candidates ranked by their overall fit with the role.
  4. Customizable Usage: You can enable the feature for specific positions whenever you think it's needed.

Visit here: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-recruiting

Check Demo Video here: AI Applicant Screening

Why This Matters for Us

This technology is more than just helpful—it's transformative for recruiters:

  • Instant Shortlists: Quickly identify the right candidates without tedious manual effort.
  • Consistent Evaluation: Every candidate is assessed using the same criteria.
  • Improved Focus: We can spend more time engaging with candidates instead of doing repetitive, copy-paste tasks.
  • Informed Decisions: Thanks to transparent skill matching and ranking.

Part of a Broader AI Strategy

What's great is that this tool is part of a larger suite of AI offerings from SAP Business AI. Other features include:

  • Crafting better job descriptions
  • Generating interview questions tailored to individual roles
  • Recommending learning paths during onboarding

Visit here: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/explore-sap-successfactors-solutions/leveraging-ai-capabilities-in-sap-successfactors

Final Thoughts

For talent acquisition professionals, this isn’t just another tech feature; it's a solution to many common hiring challenges. AI-assisted applicant screening in SAP SuccessFactors makes recruitment simpler and smarter, allowing us to focus on building more meaningful connections with the best candidates.

entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in...
entry.content:
You're absolutely right—this is a normal requirement in capital-intensive projects, engineering, construction, and defense sectors. Many organizations want visibility of:

  • Materials purchased or uploaded for a project
  • Stock sitting in inventory but earmarked for project use
  • Total committed value—even before consumption

To answer your question 'How others handle this', (to my knowledge), below are the most common approaches used across industries:

1. Use Commitment Tracking (Purchase Orders)

  • PO commitments are visible in project reports.
  • But once stock is received via 561Q, the commitment is cleared—and visibility is lost.

2. Custom Report Linking Inventory to WBS

Develop a report that shows:

  • Project stock quantity and value (from MMBE or MBBS)
  • Linked WBS element

This gives visibility without affecting cost reports.

3. Statistical Cost Posting

  • Post a manual statistical actual cost to the WBS using KB11N.
  • Use a statistical cost element so it doesn’t consume budget or distort actuals.
  • Document clearly that it represents unconsumed inventory.

4. Use Project Stock Valuation Reports

  • Reports like MBBS or S_ALR_87013558 can be customized to show stock value by WBS.
  • Not part of standard cost line items, but useful for project managers.

5. Enhanced Budgeting Logic

Some organizations extend budgeting logic to include inventory value as part of budget tracking. This requires custom development or integration with FM (Funds Management).

entry.title: Re: SXMSIF Configuration
entry.content:
Hi @naseemallika14 

Regarding your question on configuring. Let me walk you through it.

The Agency usually refers to the provider or authority responsible for the message or document exchange. It often represents a standardized body or organization defining the message formats or business rules.

The Schema defines the structure or format of the message or document. It corresponds to the XML schema or message type that governs how data elements are organized and validated in the integration.

The Party helps you identify the business partners involved in the message exchange, such as sender and receiver parties or systems. Each party represents a distinct entity or system participating in the communication scenario.

The Component typically means the technical component or system component responsible for sending or receiving the message. It helps direct and process the communication by mapping the interface to specific software components.

The SXMSIF fields help define the routing and processing of inbound and outbound messages by specifying who is sending or receiving which refers to the Party, under what Schema format, and which component or agency is involved.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in...
entry.content:
In order to make already uploaded project stock (via 561Q) visible in project cost reports—ideally without custom development, you can consider the below options:

Option 1: Controlled 221Q → 222Q with Statistical Cost Element

This is a refined version of the workaround you mentioned earlier, and while it’s not ideal, it can be used strategically:

How it works is you post 221Q to issue material to the WBS element. This creates a cost posting and consumes budget. Immediately post 222Q to return the material to project stock. This reverses the quantity movement, but the cost posting remains visible in the project line item report. Importantly, use a statistical cost element for the 221Q posting. This ensures it doesn’t consume budget or distort actual costs and the cost appears in the report, but is flagged as statistical.

Pros:
No custom report needed
Visible in standard project cost reports (CJI3, etc.)

Cons:
Requires careful configuration of cost elements
May confuse users if not documented properly

Option 2: Manual Actual Cost Posting via KB11N

If material movement isn’t feasible or desirable, you can post a manual actual cost to the WBS using KB11N. Use a statistical cost element. Reference the material document number or stock value in the text

Pros:
Clean and auditable
No physical stock movement

Cons:
Manual effort
Doesn’t reflect in inventory reports

Option 3: Reversal and Reposting with Correct Movement Type

If you're early in the project and stock hasn’t been consumed, reverse the 561Q using 562Q. Repost using a movement type that allows cost posting (e.g., 201Q or 221Q). Assign the correct WBS element and cost element

Pros:
Clean reposting with proper accounting
Reflects in both inventory and cost reports

Cons:
Operational risk if stock has already been partially consumed
May require coordination with MM and Finance teams

My recommendations would be if you want visibility without disrupting inventory, the 221Q → 222Q with statistical cost element is your best bet. It’s a controlled workaround that gives you reporting visibility while keeping the stock intact.

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration
As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025’s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

 

And the Winner Is… PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform “Legal Ease”. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. “Legal Ease” enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: “Legal Ease” addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

 

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let’s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

 

Reflections and What’s Next

The Hackathon’s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

“It is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we’ve seen incredible progress and innovation.”

 

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

 

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: Default Unit Pattern in sap/ui/core/format/NumberFormat now includes a non-breaking space
entry.content:
Intro

With a recent change in UI5 version 1.140, we have decided to include a non-breaking space in the default unit pattern. This way, the number and measure are guaranteed to stay in the same line, even with very small window sizes.

 

What's different?

If a value is formatted with sap/ui/core/format/NumberFormat.format and this function uses the default unit pattern (the fallback pattern if no other pattern is to be used) the resulting string will now include a non-breaking space between the number part and the measure part instead of a regular space. Using a respective type from sap/ui/model/type or sap/ui/model/odata/type to format values will also result in a string with a non-breaking space.

Example - Prior to the change:

  • Values to be formatted: ["50", "%"]
  • Formatted result: "50\u0020%"; \u0020 is a regular space character

Example - After to the change:

  • Values to be formatted: ["50", "%"]
  • Formatted result: "50\u00a0%"; \u00a0 is a non-breaking space character

                             

What does that mean for applications and tests?

Applications will only see a difference in the UI if the window size is small enough.
However tests might fail, as "50\u0020%" is not strict equal to "50\u00a0%": you need to adjust your test in this case.

entry.title: Re: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
Hello,

regarding my question "rating of InApp-/KeyUser-Tools" -> this is answered. (Thank you Daniel!)

I got the hint to check the FAQ of the Whitepaper -> "QC1: How does the level concept translate to the ABAP language versions (ABAP Cloud for developers, ABAP Cloud for key users)?"

All customer objects with language version “ABAP Cloud for Developers” (language version 5) and “ABAP Cloud for Key Users” (language version 2) are considered level A. This guarantees that these objects are only referencing released SAP objects.
In addition, there are objects in customer namespace which are generated when developing with ABAP Cloud for Key Users, which technically have ABAP classic language version, but which are still considered level A. With the correction from SAP note 3593439 these are also correctly detected.
All customer objects in levels B, C or D have language version ABAP classic.

Thank you and have a great day.

Regards, Thomas F!

entry.title: SAP Databricks: How to use AutoML to forecast sales data - Part 3
entry.content:
Part 1 – SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 – Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 – How to use AutoML to forecast sales data
Part 4 – End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 5 – Create inferences and endpoints for application integration with SAP Build

 

SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud

With SAP Databricks you have access to an amazing set of capabilities to work with your BDC Data Products and other data.

 

 

Let’s look at just one feature of SAP Databricks – how we can use the AutoML Forecasting feature to predict time-series data.

 

How to use AutoML to forecast sales data

How can we analyse a dataset and make forecasts without having deep understanding of machine learning?

One way is to use AutoML which will automatically create the code and run machine learning experiments behind the scenes and then provide you with the best result at the end.

SAP Databricks has a feature to build AutoML models for you – you just point it at the data and let it rip!

 

Data

For this exercise we are going to look at sales data and see if we can create an accurate forecast.

The S/4HANA system that I have available in my BDC formation has a sales_order data product available, however, after a quick investigation it's a very limited and small dataset with large multi-month gaps in the data, which is not a realistic dataset for forecasting.

For the purposes of this blog post, let's create some realistic sample data instead.

So even with AutoML - there is no excuse but to learn about your data!

 

We will create sample data and save it as a delta table: workspace.default.demo_product_sales_forecast.

 

Note:
The SAP Databricks catalog (or Unity Catalog you will see it called) structures artefacts in a format like:
- Catalog (defaulted to the name workspace but you can create many catalogs)
            - Schema (your initial schema will be called default)
                        - Table, Model, etc

 

The dataset includes several different products, and the amount sold each month over a multi-year period to consider any seasonality effects.

We will look to train a forecast model using SAP Databricks' built-in Serverless AutoML Forecast capability.

 

Note: SQL function ai_forecast()
You can also perform forecasting with a prophet based model using the SQL function ai_forecast. It only works on the serverless SQL compute however, so you cannot execute it from a Notebook which runs on the all-purpose serverless compute.
Check the ai_forecast() documentation for details and limitations.
Depending on the complexity of your data, this AutoML technique can provide better results and offers more tuning options.

 

Sample dataset

In your SAP Databricks workspace click the “Create” button and create a new python notebook.

Add a new python cell containing the following to install some modules we will use later:

%pip install databricks-automl-runtime prophet
%restart_python

And now the cell for sample data creation:

# Build a sales data set for forecasting

import pandas as pd, numpy as np
from itertools import product
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 1. CONFIG – tweak to taste
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
skus       = ["SKU_A", "SKU_B", "SKU_C", "SKU_D"]
price_map  = {"SKU_A": 25.0, "SKU_B": 40.0, "SKU_C": 33.0, "SKU_D": 18.0}
start, end = "2019-01-01", "2025-12-01"            # 7 full years, monthly freq
rng        = np.random.default_rng(42)             # reproducible

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 2. SYNTHETIC DATA FABRICATION
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
dates = pd.date_range(start, end, freq="MS")        # Month-Start stamps
# WEEKLY
# dates = pd.date_range("2019-01-07", "2025-12-29", freq="W-MON")
# or DAILY
# dates = pd.date_range("2019-01-01", "2025-12-31", freq="D")
rows  = []
for sku, ts in product(skus, dates):
    #   volume dynamics ------------------------------------------------------
    base   = {"SKU_A":380, "SKU_B":240, "SKU_C":310, "SKU_D":700}[sku]
    trend  = {"SKU_A":  6, "SKU_B":  9, "SKU_C":  4, "SKU_D": -3}[sku] * (ts.year-2019)
    seas   = 80 * np.sin(2*np.pi*ts.month/12 + {"SKU_A":0, "SKU_B":1,
                                                "SKU_C":2, "SKU_D":3}[sku])
    promo  = 120 if ts.month in (11, 12) else 0     # holiday lift
    noise  = rng.normal(0, 40)
    units  = max(0, int(base + trend + seas + promo + noise))
    
    #   revenue = units × price ± small discount noise -----------------------
    net_amt = round(units * price_map[sku] * rng.uniform(0.97, 1.03), 2)
    
    rows.append((sku, ts, units, net_amt))

df = pd.DataFrame(rows, columns=["SKU",              #   ← series identifier
                                 "SalesOrderDate",   #   ← time column
                                 "UnitsSold",        #   ← target 1
                                 "TotalNetAmount"])  #   ← target 2 (optional)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 3. LAND AS A DELTA TABLE
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
(spark.createDataFrame(df)
      .write.format("delta").mode("overwrite")
      .saveAsTable("demo_product_sales_forecast"))

# Quick visual sanity-check (optional)
display(spark.table("demo_product_sales_forecast")
              .orderBy("SalesOrderDate", "SKU")
              .limit(12))

Execute these cells and you will now have a new table in the catalog called demo_product_sales_forecast.

 

AutoML Forecast – configure and train

Now we have our sample data generated by our python notebook, let’s use SAP Databricks inbuilt function to create a machine learning model using AutoML.

 

Steps within the SAP Databricks cockpit:

  1. Navigate to AI/ML -> Experiments in the left menu bar and click the forecasting (preview) box


     



  2. Populate the required fields.
    Enter workspace.default.demo_product_sales_forecast as the training data (this is the sample data table we previously created with a python notebook)

  3. Choose SalesOrderDate as the Time Column

  4. Choose UnitsSold (or TotalNetAmount) for the Target Column (the value we want to be able to predict)

  5. Choose Monthly for Forecast Frequency

  6. Set 12 months for the Forecast Horizon

  7. Enter workspace.default as the prediction path (or any other Unity Catalog path of your choosing) and demo_product_sales_forecast_predictions as the prediction table

  8. Enter the location where you want the model saved and its name (e.g. workspace.default and sales_forecast)

  9. Under Advanced Options, choose column SKU as the time-series identifier (IMPORTANT! Since this dataset covers multiple different products)

 

Finally, click Start Training.

 

With this sample dataset, training can take around 20mins.
AutoML is pre-processing the data, tuning a forecasting model
by building many different types of models with different 
hyperparameters and finally training (fit) on the data using 
the best model and parameters.

 

See it creating experiments as it tunes the model now:

 

SAP Databricks uses the MLFlow frameworks for MLOps, which enables history to be captured and for you to create reproducible workflows.

 

Training results

At the end of the training run the best model is chosen based on a hyperparameter search and saved (and registered) to the unity catalog in SAP Databricks.

 

A table of predictions is created as a result (you provided the name when configuring AutoML). The best trained model is also saved and registered into the unity catalog (with the name you entered e.g. sales_forecast).

 

View the forecast result

You can switch back to your python notebook (or open the SAP Databricks SQL editor) to view the data with:

%sql
select * from demo_product_sales_foreacast_predictions

 

Visual sanity check.

We can use the following code cell in your notebook to plot the historical (training) data and extend it with the 12-month forecast.

import pandas as pd, matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# ── grab data ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
hist_tbl = "demo_product_sales_forecast"
pred_tbl = "demo_product_sales_foreacast_predictions"   # name from AutoML wizard

hist = spark.table(hist_tbl).toPandas()
pred = spark.table(pred_tbl).toPandas()

# ensure date columns are pandas Timestamps
hist["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(hist["SalesOrderDate"])
pred["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(pred["SalesOrderDate"])

# ── plot per SKU ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
for sku in hist["SKU"].unique():
    h = hist[hist["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    p = pred[pred["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 4))
    
    ax.plot(h["SalesOrderDate"], h["UnitsSold"], label="actual", linewidth=2)
    ax.plot(p["SalesOrderDate"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"],
            label="forecast", linestyle="--")
    
    ax.fill_between(
        p["SalesOrderDate"],
        p["predicted_UnitsSold_lower"],
        p["predicted_UnitsSold_upper"],
        alpha=0.25,
        label="95 % Confidence"
    )
    
    ax.set_title(f"Units Sold – {sku}")
    ax.set_xlabel("Date")
    ax.set_ylabel("Units")
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True)
    
    plt.show()

 

Output for one of the products:

 

We can see it looks pretty good and has captured the cyclical nature of the sales data well.

 

Let’s now back-test the forecast to see how good it works and compare it to the last 12 months of training data. We can do this by cutting off the training data 12 months early and forecasting for that cut-off 12 months.

Note: what we are doing here is actually leaking training data into our test which is bad practice in a real life scenario but it's just a quick way to visualise how the forecast works. In real life we should carve out some of our training data (e.g. the last months or year maybe) and perform the below test on that data.

Use this cell to plot actual vs. prediction.

# 📊 Back-test: forecast last 12 months per SKU and plot
import mlflow, pandas as pd, numpy as np, matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# ── 1. LOAD THE REGISTERED MODEL ──────────────────────────────────────────
uc_model_path     = "workspace.default.sales_forecast"     # fully-qualified UC model
model_version_uri = f"models:/{uc_model_path}@most_recent"

mlflow.set_registry_uri("databricks-uc")                  # point MLflow at UC
model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(model_version_uri)       # pulls pipeline incl. featurizer

# ── 2. HISTORICAL DATA ────────────────────────────────────────────────────
hist = (spark.table("demo_product_sales_forecast")
           .toPandas()
           .sort_values(["SKU", "SalesOrderDate"]))
hist["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(hist["SalesOrderDate"])

# ── 3. HOLD-OUT = last 12 rows per SKU ────────────────────────────────────
holdout_idx = hist.groupby("SKU").tail(12).index
score_df    = hist.loc[holdout_idx].copy().reset_index(drop=True)
train_df    = hist.drop(index=holdout_idx)

# ── 4. PREDICT ON HOLD-OUT ────────────────────────────────────────────────
features = score_df.drop(columns=["UnitsSold"])           # only drop the target
yhat     = model.predict(features).reset_index(drop=True) # returns a Series named 'yhat'
score_df["predicted_UnitsSold"] = yhat                    # attach forecast column

# (optional) prediction intervals if the pipeline supports them:
# try:
#     pi = model.predict_interval(features, coverage=0.95).reset_index(drop=True)
#     score_df = pd.concat([score_df, pi], axis=1)
# except AttributeError:
#     pass

# ── 5. SMAPE helper ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────
def smape(actual, forecast):
    denom = np.abs(actual) + np.abs(forecast)
    return np.mean(np.where(denom == 0, 0, 200 * np.abs(actual - forecast) / denom))

# ── 6. PLOT PER SKU ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────
for sku in hist["SKU"].unique():
    h = hist[hist["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    p = score_df[score_df["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")

    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 4))
    ax.plot(h["SalesOrderDate"], h["UnitsSold"],
            label="actual", lw=2)
    ax.plot(p["SalesOrderDate"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"],
            label="back-test forecast", lw=2, ls="--", color="orange")

    # uncomment if interval columns exist
    # if {"predicted_UnitsSold_lower", "predicted_UnitsSold_upper"}.issubset(p.columns):
    #     ax.fill_between(p["SalesOrderDate"],
    #                     p["predicted_UnitsSold_lower"],
    #                     p["predicted_UnitsSold_upper"],
    #                     color="orange", alpha=0.15, label="95 % PI")

    sku_smape = smape(p["UnitsSold"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"])
    #ax.set_title(f"{sku} – Back-test SMAPE: {sku_smape:.2%}")
    ax.set_title(f"{sku} – Back-test SMAPE: {sku_smape/100:.2%}")
    ax.set_xlabel("Date"); ax.set_ylabel("Units")
    ax.legend(); ax.grid(True)
    plt.show()

 

 

Conclusion

Forecasting time-series data with SAP Databricks is made far easier thanks to AutoML which takes away the work of cleaning your data (pre-processing step); hyperparameter tuning by building many model experiments and capturing them in MLFow (tuning step) and finally training the best model architecture to suit your data (training step).

You might also be wondering – why – why bother with this and instead use an LLM to do it all? Well, the answer is that LLM’s just aren’t that good at working with tabular data. For very small datasets – absolutely – throw it into ChatGPT for some analysis. But for real scenarios we still rely on classic machine learning approaches as shown here…

entry.title: Future of Feature Toggles
entry.content:
Dear all, 

I am currently member in a migration project to S4 Hana.
We currently use a self-developed framework that also has a "feature toggle" functionality.

When I looked into the topic of feature toggles a few years ago, I discovered that SAP has an own implementation of feature toggles in S4.

Now I wanted to test this and the result is:

  • Legacy feature toggles are marked as deprecated in Eclipse.
  • Switch-Based Feature Toggles cannot be created on customer systems.

What is the future here in on premise / private cloud?

The idea of a feature toggle is a temporary switch. As soon as the feature has been fully developed and rolled out to all users, it should be removed.
Therefore, in my opinion, there is nothing to be said against the usage of "legacy feature toggles", as they are meant only to be used temporarily in the code.

In case the framework is deleted by SAP, the legacy feature toggles should have been removed and deleted again following the idea of clean code.

At least I do not find "cl_feature_toggle"  in the current simplification database :-).

What's your opinion?
Is there a better alternative?

Regards
Jürgen

entry.title: Re: Restricting BNK_MONI T-code
entry.content:
BNK_MONI is a monitoring transaction, not a posting or execution transaction. It’s primarily used to view payment statuses and batches.

SAP designed it to check F_STAT_MON, which includes fields like:

  • Authorization group
  • Payment medium status
  • Payment run status

It does not include company code as a restriction field, which means you can't directly restrict access by company code using standard authorization objects.

Here are some approaches and Best Practices which you can also try

1. Authorization Groups
Assign different authorization groups to payment batches based on company code. Then restrict F_STAT_MON by authorization group. This requires customizing your payment configuration to tag batches appropriately.

2. Custom Enhancement (BAdI or User Exit)
Implement a custom check via enhancement in BNK_MONI or related function modules. You can intercept the selection logic and restrict based on user’s company code authorization.

3. Role-Based UI Restriction
If you're using SAP Fiori apps, you can apply restriction types at the business catalog level. For example, restrict by company code using the “Company Code” restriction field in the role definition.

entry.title: Employee data review and farewell message task performed by HRADMIN in offboarding
entry.content:
Hi Everyone

I created a business rule where the Employee Data Review is performed by HRADMIN, and the Write Farewell Message in Offboarding task is also performed by HRADMIN.

Steps to configure:

  1. Create the Business Rule

  2. Under Onboarding General Settings, create a Responsible Group and assign all country-specific dynamic groups to it. Then, assign this responsible group to the Farewell Message task.

  3. Create country-specific dynamic groups and assign them to the responsible group you created

 

Regards,

Garima Saxena

entry.title: Re: SAP CIS Identity Provisioning Service integration with SAP HANA Cloud, HANA Database
entry.content:
Dear @pavlomelnyk ,

Thank you for your excellent blog post on setting up the provisioning framework to SAP HANA Cloud DB via IPS. Following your guidance, we successfully implemented the scenario.

We now have a new requirement to assign an additional Identity Provider (SAML) to the user record for an SAC Live Data connection. Our goal is to achieve this through IPS provisioning by setting the SAC SAML IdP in addition to the existing JWT provider.

However, it appears that the SCIM schema supports only one IdP entry per user. When we attempted to provision an additional SAML IdP via IPS, it overwrote the existing JWT provider in the user record. We confirmed that it is possible to maintain an additional IdP manually via the UI, which we did for testing purposes.

To verify this, we performed a GET request via Postman to check the SCIM schema for the user. Unfortunately, the additional IdP did not appear in the schema, leading us to conclude that only one IdP can be provisioned via IPS.

We have also opened a ticket with SAP Support. While they are currently investigating, they advised us to post this question in the SAP Community as well. We believe this may be a broader use case, as there are scenarios where users would need both IdPs:

  • JWT for SSO access at the DB level

  • SAML IdP for consuming data via SAC Live Data connection

Do you have any experience or insights regarding this requirement?

Thank you in advance for your feedback.

Kind regards,

Alex
